descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
This is course 1 in a two-quarter sequence on classical electrodynamics. Specific topics to be covered:

Quarter 1 (PHYS333-1): Electrostatics and Magnetostatics. Electric charge, Coulomb's law, field and potential descriptions of electrostatics; Boundary value problems and analytical techniques for exact and approximate solutions of the Laplace and Poisson equations; Electrostatics in the presence of conductors and dielectrics; Steady currents and Lorentz force, field and potential descriptions of magnetostatics; Magnetic fields in materials.

Quarter 2 (PHYS333-2): Electrodynamics. Faraday's law and (Maxwell's version of) Ampere's law, Maxwell equations; Potential formulation of electrodynamics; Poynting's theorem and other conservation laws in electrodynamics; Electromagnetic waves; Electromagnetic radiation;

PHYS361-0 follows this sequence with discussion of special relativity and electromagnetism.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
Prerequisites for this class are a background in calculus based introductory physics
(Physics 135-1,2,3 or the equivalent) and advanced mathematics beyond introductory differential and integral calculus. Familiarity with basics of ordinary differential equations, vector calculus (including Gauss's and Stokes's theorem) and linear algebra are expected (Math 215, 219, and 221, or the equivalent).

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Three hours of lectures, one hour of discussion (if needed) per week plus weekly graded problem sets.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: 35% for weekly homework sets and graded quizzes, 25% for the midterm examination and 40% for the final examination.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Introduction to Electrodynamics, 4th Edition David J. Griffiths
